description: A rich, thick, and deeply flavorful stew from Northern Uganda made from finely pounded fresh cassava leaves, slow-cooked with groundnuts (peanuts), and often enriched with fish or meat. It has a distinctive dark green color and a unique, slightly bitter, earthy taste.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Essami is a cornerstone of Acholi and Lango cuisine. The process of pounding the leaves is a communal and labor-intensive activity, often done by women using a large mortar and pestle. It is a dish that signifies patience, tradition, and community. It's a nutritious and filling meal, central to the food culture of Northern Uganda.

ingredients.name: Fresh Cassava Leaves
ingredients.notes: Young, tender leaves are best. Thoroughly washed.

ingredients.name: Smoked Fish or Meat (Optional)
ingredients.notes: Deboned and flaked (fish) or cut into pieces (meat)

ingredients.name: Potash (Potassium Carbonate) or Baking Soda
ingredients.notes: A tiny amount to tenderize the leaves and preserve color (traditional but optional)

utensils.name: Grinding Stone (Modern Alternative: Blender)
utensils.notes: A blender can be used as a modern alternative to pounding, though the texture will differ.

steps.instruction: Wash the cassava leaves thoroughly in several changes of water to remove all dirt and sand. Drain.

Using a large mortar and pestle (or a blender in batches), pound/blend the cassava leaves until they become a fine, dark green paste. This is the most crucial and labor-intensive step. Add a very small amount of water if using a blender to facilitate the process.
In a large, heavy pot, heat the palm oil over medium heat. Add the chopped onions and sauté until soft.
Add the chopped tomatoes and cook until they break down and soften.
Add the pounded cassava leaves to the pot. Stir well to combine with the onion and tomato base.
Dissolve the groundnut paste in about 2 cups of water to create a smooth, creamy liquid. Pour this into the pot with the leaves.
Add the remaining water, salt, the whole pierced chili pepper, and the optional potash or baking soda. Stir everything thoroughly.

Bring the stew to a boil, then reduce the heat to very low. Cover the pot and let it simmer gently for at least 1.5 to 2 hours. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking at the bottom. The long, slow cooking is essential for developing the flavor and tenderizing the leaves.

cooking_indicators.visual: The stew will darken significantly, thicken to a paste-like consistency, and the oil will start to separate and rise to the top.

steps.instruction: If using smoked fish or meat, add it in the last 30 minutes of cooking to heat through and infuse its flavor.
Once the stew has reached a thick, rich consistency and the raw taste of the leaves has completely cooked out, it is ready. Adjust salt to taste.
Serve the Essami hot in a bowl.

serving_suggestions: Traditionally served with Atap (Millet Bread), Boiled Sweet Potatoes, Cassava (Mwogo), or Posho (Ugali).
